awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms of small RNA-mediated translation repression in Chlamydomonas
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will have broad scientific impact by generating basic knowledge needed for the genetic improvement of microalgae, which are emerging as a suitable resource for the production of biomaterials, nutraceuticals, and biofuels. The specific focus of the work will be on understanding how small RNA molecules regulate the process of protein synthesis, using a unicellular green alga as the model. The research will involve researchers at undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral levels, thus contributing to the training of 'knowledge workers' whose specialized skills will enable them to work productively within STEM industries and occupations. Results and products will be disseminated broadly through publication in scientific journals, outreach activities, and contributions to an algal resource center. The project will also broaden participation through the recruitment and education of members of underrepresented groups in the sciences and first generation students.  

Small RNAs play important regulatory roles in multiple processes, and RNA interference (RNAi) has become a valuable tool for reverse genetic studies and practical applications in medicine and agriculture. Whereas many aspects of small RNA function have been studied in detail, the mechanisms of small RNA-mediated translational repression remain poorly understood. This project will address this gap in understanding by studying how small RNAs function to inhibit protein synthesis at post-initiation steps. The experiments will be carried out in a unicellular green alga, Chlamydomonas. In preliminary experiments, a genetic screen for mutants impaired in small RNA-mediated translational repression identified genes involved in TOR (Target of Rapamycin) signaling and polypeptide prenylation pathways, thus implicating these processes as key steps in small RNA-mediated function.  To follow up on these observations, experiments will be conducted to: (i) characterize the negative interplay between RAPTOR (Regulatory Associated Protein of Target Of Rapamycin) and the TOR kinase with RNAi effector complexes, mostly through proteomic approaches; (ii) characterize a mutant deleted for a homolog of the Vasa Intronic Gene (VIG) product, via the identification of VIG interactors and their effect(s) on ribosome function; and (iii) identify new factors required for sRNA-mediated translation repression, by means of an insertional mutagenesis screen. The findings are expected to provide new insights into how small RNAs function in translational repression.

por.por_cntn:
RNA interference (RNAi) is an evolutionarily conserved process in eukaryotes by which small RNAs generally induce the silencing of cognate sequences through a variety of mechanisms, including RNA degradation, translation repression, transcriptional inhibition and/or, in a few organisms, DNA elimination. In plants and animals, small RNAs play important roles in gene regulation and the control of developmental processes as well as in defense responses against transposons and viruses. However, several aspects of small RNA function, particularly the mechanism(s) of translation repression, remain poorly characterized. The research supported by this award was designed to characterize how RNAi represses protein translation in the green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. In addition, microalgae are attracting attention as suitable feedstocks for the production of diverse biomaterials/nutraceuticals and even carbon-neutral biofuels. However, one key constraint to their industrial development is the very limited knowledge of the regulatory mechanisms that control gene expression and metabolism. The findings of this project contribute to the understanding of the biological role(s) of small RNAs in green algae and to the development of reliable tools for engineering their genomes.

In Chlamydomonas, several metazoans and land plants, emerging evidence indicates that ribosome-associated transcripts can be translationally repressed by small RNAs without substantial mRNA destabilization. Throughout this project, we have found that Chlamydomonas VIG1, a homolog of the Drosophila melanogaster Vasa Intronic Gene and a member of a highly conserved protein family in eukaryotes, is involved in this process. VIG1 appears to be an ancillary ribosomal constituent since it associates with several translation initiation factors and ribosomal proteins. Moreover, a VIG1-deleted mutant is hypersensitive to exposure to the translation elongation inhibitor cycloheximide, suggesting that VIG1 may have some role(s) in ribosome function/structure. VIG1 also co-purifies with core components of small RNA effector complexes, such as ARGONAUTE3, and it is required for the small RNA-mediated translation repression of ribosome-associated transcripts. Yet, the exact mechanism by which VIG1 may contribute to translation repression remains under investigation.

RNA programmable site-specific nucleases (such as the CRISPR/Cas system) cause DNA double-strand breaks at specific genomic sites, which can be repaired by different pathways. In many eukaryotes, including Chlamydomonas, the repair of these induced DNA double-strand breaks occurs preferentially by error-prone mechanisms, precluding the introduction of precise nucleotide changes in genes of interest. To overcome this limitation, we developed a method to guide the precise repair of DNA double-strand breaks by homology-directed repair mechanisms. Two in vitro-assembled RNA-guided nucleases and two single-stranded oligodeoxynucleotides, which serve as templates for the repair, were co-introduced into Chlamydomonas cells. One of the oligonucleotides converts an endogenous gene into a selectable marker, and the other directs specific nucleotide changes into another gene of interest. This method represents a transgene-free strategy for the precise modification of algal genes at their native locus.

To perform these studies, we also generated essential resources useful for the scientific community, such as mutant and genetically modified algal strains and high-quality RNA and small RNA sequencing datasets. Two postdoctoral fellows, four graduate students, eight undergraduate students, and two high school students participated in research and community engagement activities associated with this award. These individuals received training in research methodology, mentoring, critical thinking skills, and aspects related to career development. These educational activities contribute to preparing knowledge workers whose specialized skills will enable them to work productively within STEM occupations and industries.
